body: @SDASDASA can u open source your predict code ? I have met some problem, I can't predict image, thanks a lot
I find that CUDA 8 is released already! I installed it and update all software to newest, now I can confirm that MXNet can be compiled with GCC 6 and CUDA 8 in Arch Linux.

@pluskid Thx for your reply. I tried the nnvm branch, but got no improvement in speed. Both are around 1150 samples/s. And the new api gpu memory is about 10 times bigger(8692M vs 962M). 
I think the construction and destruction time of graph can be hidden by some asynchronous methods. For example , we can construct a new graph, while training process of the last batch is not finished.

Hi @feiyulv , I also observed the low efficiency of RNN, which includes low speed and unstable GPU util. I thought that it is because a new graph is always created for a new batch. But after checking the code, it seems that `DataParallelExecutorManager` will not create a new graph for a seen length key and I am getting more confused.

@pluskid Any idea about this issue? I tried several times to sell mxnet to others, however, for the current performance on RNN, it might be less convincing to encourage NLP people to use it.

It must came as a surprise to change the naming of symbol_inception-bn.py. If it break your model, please stick to the previous symbol.py. If not, this change will be justified by the following account.

The previous version of symbol.py does not correspond to pretrained model, either. To accurately reflect the previous model the symbol would be:

``` python
# stage 2
conv_2_reduce = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=pool1, num_filter=64, kernel=(1, 1), stride=(1, 1), pad=(0, 0), name='conv_2_reduce')
bn_2_1 = mx.symbol.BatchNorm(data=conv_2_reduce, name='bn_2_1')
relu_2_1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=bn_2_1, act_type='relu', name='relu_2_1')
conv2 = ConvFactory(data=relu_2_1, num_filter=192, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), pad=(1, 1), name='2')
pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=conv2, kernel=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), name='pool2', pool_type='max')
```

This seems strange so a change from '2_reduce' and '2_1' to '2_red' is proposed. We also change 'conv_conv1' and 'bn_conv1' to 'conv_1' and 'bn_1' since it is consistent throughout entire network.

Actually it is not likely to reproduce the previous model `inception-bn_old.tar.gz` since pooling behavior is changed.

The parameters of eps, bn_mom and fix_gamma is a practical training choice. Current setting works and should be further adjusted to suit your need.

When I was arranging my code, I found that the segmentation fault problem happened after I imported ipdb. So I removed ipdb module, and the problem has gone. Could you please check this?
how to check without any code.

Have you changed the gcc version? Ubuntu 16.04 should come with gcc5. One possible path (not easy) is to upgrade to the last ubuntu 16.04.2, it will come with gcc5, then try again. If you are using CUDA 8 you need a patch for the new gcc. Chech this [tutorial](https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/machinelearning/2016/09/15/building-deep-neural-networks-in-the-cloud-with-azure-gpu-vms-mxnet-and-microsoft-r-server/) for more info.

``` python
import numpy as np
import sys, os
import subprocess

import mxnet as mx

import ipdb

import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

# from net.create_12net import *

root_dir = os.getenv('HOME') + '/mxnet/fd'
sz_patch = (12, 12)

### train
path_list = root_dir + '/data/imagerec/12net'
if not os.path.exists(path_list):
    os.makedirs(path_list)

list_prefix_train = 'train_12net'
# fn_lst_train = os.path.join(path_list, list_prefix_train + '.lst')
fn_rec_train = os.path.join(path_list, list_prefix_train + '.rec')

### val
list_prefix_val = 'val_12net'
# fn_lst_val = os.path.join(path_list, list_prefix_val + '.lst')
fn_rec_val = os.path.join(path_list, list_prefix_val + '.rec')

train_iter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        data_name='data', 
        label_name='label', 
        path_imgrec=fn_rec_train, # .rec file with images, multi-dimensional labels packed together
        # path_imglist=fn_lst_train,
        data_shape=(3,12,12),
        label_width=16,
        batch_size=256,
        mean_r=127,
        mean_g=97,
        mean_b=88)

val_iter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        data_name='data', 
        label_name='label', 
        path_imgrec=fn_rec_val, 
        # path_imglist=fn_lst_val,
        data_shape=(3,12,12),
        label_width=16,
        batch_size=128,
        mean_r=127,
        mean_g=97,
        mean_b=88) 

print 'Done.'
```
Rebased to master. Let me know any pending action items from my side.

For test data, use 
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/22970009/val_12net.rec

I also tried to implement the drop path method with a simple `CustomOp` layer, which accepts two input and randomly outputs the identity or the summed one. 

But I did not achieve good results with this layer, a little worse than the original resnet.

I observe that your implementation is quite different. Is my idea OK?
@vchuravy Yes, doctest might be a good idea.

@zlmzju I'm not sure exactly how you did it. The implementation above is also slightly worse than the reported number. Roughly 9% error vs 5% error IIRC. But the ResNet architecture are slightly different.

@zlmzju I see. I think stochastic depth might have two main effects: one is regularization, and the other is saving computation. The reason that I use imperative scheduling is to avoid extra computation when a branch is skipped. The `CustomOp` way you used might not be able to save the computation. Yes, I agree. It will be very useful for the community if we are able to reproduce those results and have complete examples.
@pluskid yes, you are right, your implementation is better. I can help test some examples based on my resnet implementation (resnet-110 5%~6% error with so many epochs).

My cuda version is 7.5,GPU is GT730。

@starimpact is correct. `weight` and `bias` are both variables not values.

You should use it like

```
data <- mx.symbol.Variable('data')
w <- mx.symbol.Variable('w')
conv1 <- mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=c(5,5), weight = w, num_filter=20)
```

@qggjonny  When I installed win2012 version and call `import mxnet` in python console, it tells me that `missing cudnn64_70.dll`, but I have put my cudnn in the correct folder and cudnn v5 & v5.1 are both named `cudnn64_5.dll`, can you look at the `3rdparty` folder and see what is your cudnn version?

@magic282 If you use the bucket, the gpu util will be unstable at the beginning, but after all the buckets are constructed, gpu util will be stable. In my case, I do't use bucket key, and create a new symbol  for each batch. You can try the new nnvm, it will be faster. Bucket is a little ugly, it forces more padding, and has to calculate bucket keys and bucket size for different dataset.
@pluskid The result I provided yesterday was wrong, nnvm is really faster than the original mxnet for variable length lstm(1400 vs 1150), but the gpu util is still unstable. I check the code in model.py, the forward and backward caller of executor is asynchronous, so theoretically the time of symbol construction/destruction can be overlapped by training. The drop of  gpu util may be caused by the construction/destruction time is too long to be hidden. Is that possible to support dynamical graph construction as theano? Like @magic282  I met the same problem when spreading the use of mxnet in my colleagues.
@feiyulv I did use buckets. But I still observed unstable GPU util for entire training phase.

so if want define different weights and bias for different convolutional layer, like weight = 0.0001, bias = 0.0002 for first convolutional layer, weight = 0.001, bias = 0.002 for second convolutional layer, how should I write the script to achieve this?

@magic282  different length may also cause the fluctuation of gpu util. You can check the log, the speed at the beginning is lower than the speed when all buckets are constructed.
I've fixed the case for RCNN and have removed the warm-up scheduler. The mAP on VOC2007 is 0.6976 after training for 10 epochs on a single GPU using `train_end2end.py`

@sxjscience great!  

would you also give the result to the https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rcnn/README.md, make a table of this two result(alternate and end2end ), i have test the alternate model before, map is about 0.6954.

OK, should be something like this. I'll update later.

## Results

|  | Training Data | Test Data | mAP |
| --- | :-: | :-: | --: |
| FasterRCNN (alternate) | VOC 07 trainval | VOC 07 test | 69.54% |
| FasterRCNN (approx-end2end) | VOC 07 trainval | VOC 07 test | 69.76% |

Here you are an example with R (mx.callback.plot.train.metric):

`
nnet_strain <- mx.symbol.Variable('data') %>%
                 mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name = 'fc1', num_hidden = 5) %>%
                 mx.symbol.Activation(name = 'relu1', act_type ='relu') %>%
                 mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name = 'fc2', num_hidden = 5) %>%
                 mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(name = 'softmax')
                 #mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(name = 'logisticregression')

### mx.callback.plot.train.metric

mx.callback.plot.train.metric <- function(period, logger = NULL){
  function(iteration, nbatch, env, verbose=TRUE){
    if (nbatch %% period == 0 && !is.null(env$metric)){
      N = env$end.round
      result <- env$metric$get(env$train.metric)
      plot(c(0.0, 1) ~ c(0, N), col=NA, ylab=paste0("Train ", result$name), xlab="")
      logger$train <- c(logger$train, result$value)
      lines(logger$train, lwd=3, col="red")
    }
    return(TRUE)
  }
}

devices <- mx.cpu() #mx.ctx.default(mx.cpu(1))

logger <- mx.metric.logger$new()

tic = proc.time()

mx.set.seed(1)

model_strain <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(nnet_strain,
                                     X = t(strain[,-c(1)]),
                                     y = strain[,1],
                                     ctx = devices,
                                     num.round = 1500,
                                     array.batch.size = 100,
                                     learning.rate = 0.001,
                                     momentum = 0.9,
                                     eval.metric = mx.metric.accuracy,
                                     initializer = mx.init.uniform(0.01),
                                     epoch.end.callback = mx.callback.plot.train.metric(100, logger))

proc.time() - tic

logger_df <- data.frame(Interation=1:length(logger$train), Accuracy = 100_logger$train, Train_error = 100_(1-logger$train))

rm(logger)

ggplot(logger_df, aes(Interation, Accuracy)) + geom_line(lwd=1, col=I("darkblue")) +
  xlab("ITERATION") + ylab("TRAIN ACCURACY (%)") + theme_economist() + scale_colour_economist() +  ylim(0, 100) +
  theme(axis.text = element_text(size=14, colour=NULL),
        axis.title.x = element_text(face="bold", colour="#990000", size=20),
        axis.title.y = element_text(face="bold", colour="#990000", size=20))

`

There is generally no need to use multi processing with mxnet if you are smart about where to sync. Everything is automatically parallelized by the engine.
If you have to use multi processing, use distributed kvstore. I think you can have multiple workers on the same machine. @mli

@piiswrong 

Thanks a lot for your reply! I understand your idea,  MXNet is truly good at asynchronous computation.

However, my case is to develop the ["Asynchronous Method for Deep Reinforcement Learning"(A3C) algorithm](https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.01783). 

It is **multi-processor computing on a single machine with centralized neural network parameters**, which usually involves more than 16 parallel actor-learners. 

Multi-threading is not feasible, partly because the RL environements are not thread-safe. 

Distributed KVStore is also not optimal because it will introduce too much overhead caused by network communication.

Numpy has an API that allows as to create an array from a existing memory buffer, which enables multiprocessing.

I would be willing to develop such functionality for KVStore that supports efficient single-machine, multi-process communication based on shared memory, given that it's not supported yet.

Thanks!

Peter
